author: legotrainfan
title: 90 degrees
review:
This is a 90 degree rail crossing. For model railways there are 10 and 15 degree crossing. By using them you can build quite complex shunting areas; shunting areas that are impossible to build with this rail crossing. You can only use it to build bigger or smaller loops for which you need lots of curved rails. 

I must admit I expect much from LEGO. LEGO trains have been designed for children. So it's no surprise that 10 and 15 degree rail crossings do not exist. And somehow you'll definitely find a way to integrate this piece of rail in your track layout. 

I sometimes ask myself why this set was released so late. The first 9V trains and rails were available in 1991. This set could be bought for the first time in 1999.

author: PMC_5_Yr_Old_SS
title: Just what you think it is
review:
As the title says, this "set" is just what you think it is.

Just one piece, but it really adds to any 9v Lego train layout. It makes a figure-eight track layout possible. The figure-eight is all I've used it for, though I'm sure it could be used for other layouts.

If you like neat train track layouts, this is a very good addition to your collection.

Pros
-Makes figure-eight layouts possible
-Reasonable cost

Cons
-Only one piece
-limited uses

Overall, a very good set, if you like track layouts. Worthless if you don't.
